description: From German Seston, from Ancient Greek σηστόν (sēstón), neuter of σηστός (sēstós, “sifter”) , verbal adjective of σήθω (sḗthō, “I strain, filter”). Coined by analogy with plankton.

entries.meaning: All particulate matter suspended in bodies of water such as lakes and seas, including plankton, organic detritus, and inorganic material.
